page.title: 01GENERAL DESCRIPTION
page.content: Nearly all the land is pasture, but a few fields are used for crops. There are two small settlements, Idridgehay and Shottle. Idridgehay is set in a rural area, and so is Shottle. The farmland is for cattle and just about all fields are used for grass. Idridgehay is set in the bottom of a valley. On one side of the valley Alport Hill is the last hill of the pennines. It divides the area into two. Idridgehay has one main road and only one railway that only carries cargo. Idridgehay is best described as a village, where as Shottle is a hamlet. The Ecclesbourne river flows through the valley. Idridgehay has a school, pub, church, and a shop that is a post office and petrol station. Shottle has a few houses and farms, and a church with a monthly service.
